titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Genealogical Bureau of Virginia, 1923-1945
titlestmt.subtitle: Genealogical Bureau of Virginia 52989
titlestmt.author: Trenton Hizer

publicationstmt.date: © 2020 By The Library of Virginia. All Rights Reserved.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid derived from MARC record by Trenton Hizer, 10 June 1020

titlepage.titleproper: A Guide to the Genealogical Bureau of Virginia, 1923-1945
titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
the Library of Virginia 52989

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Genealogical Bureau of Virginia, 1923-1945

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Genealogical Bureau of Virginia records, 1923-1945.Accession 52989. Business records collection, The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Virginia.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Joel P. Cocks, Richmond, Virginia, and William L. Lawrence, Gloucester, Virginia.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Genealogical Bureau of Virginia was founded by William Macfarlane Jones (1868-1951). The Bureau conducted genealogical research in Virginia records for clients.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Records, 1923-1945, of the Genealogical Bureau of Virginia, located in Richmond, Virginia, consisting of abstracts of deeds, wills, birth, marriage, and death records; correspondence, genealogical charts and notes; research records, and other documents detailing the Bureau's genealogical research for clients regarding ancestors who lived in Virginia. Genealogical research was often conducted to assist clients interested in membership in societies like the Daughters of the American Revolution or the Sons of the American Revolution.

did.unittitle: Series I: Family files.

scopecontent.p: Family files consist of genealogical research on various families and is arranged alphabetically. Records contain information on births, deaths, marriages, and family relations.

Series II: Client files.

scopecontent.p: Client files consist of genealogical research conducted for clients of the Bureau. Records are organized by client number created by the Bureau. Records contain information on births, deaths, marriages, and family relations. No client files numbered 56, 96, 235, 237-300.

Series III: General records.

scopecontent.p: General records consist of abstracts of marriage records, notes, and other materials regarding the work of the Bureau.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous genealogical notes (family: Massie, Osborne)
Marriage records from the Hustings Court of the City of Richmond, 1800-1850 (typescript compilation)
Marriage bond abstracts from Hustings Court of Richmond, 1802-1813, also some Hanover marriages, September 1924
Richmond City marriage bonds compilation (with some emancipation deeds), 1789-1807
Cover for marriage records city of Richmond compilation
Chesterfield County marriage records compilation, 1793-1819
Marriage records from Halifax and Louisa Counties
Middlesex County, Virginia, marriage records compiled by the Genealogical Bureau of Virginia
Various county records--Augusta, Botetourt, Hanover, King George, Middlesex, Orange, Richmond, York, and Kentucky
W. Mac. Jones notebook (1 of 3)
W. Mac. Jones notebook (2 of 3)
W. Mac. Jones notebook, 1924
List of charts
Index to Quaker records of Nansemond County
A Kin Study by John Eacott Manahan of Scottsville, Virginia
Miscellaneous papers
Series IV: Non-Bureau records.

scopecontent.p: Non-Bureau records consist of papers of the Cobbs Hall Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, including Bible records, biographies, and grave sites of members and Revolutionary War soldiers; correspondence of Jane Parker of Richmond regarding genealogy and the Mary Ball Memorial Museum and Library; articles; notes; and miscellaneous papers.

did.unittitle: Cobbs Hall Chapter (DAR) Genealogical Records Committee reports and papers, 1972-1980, including Grandparent Project papers
Cobbs Hall Chapter (DAR) correspondence, 1978-1979, including Grandparent Project
Cobbs Hall Chapter (DAR) Bible records, Chilton family genealogy, John Mavity autobiography
Cobbs Hall Chapter (DAR) Within the Court House at Lancaster
Cobbs Hall Chapter (DAR) graves of DAR members marked, 1977-1980
Cobbs Hall Chapter (DAR) graves of Revolutionary War soldiers marked
Jane Parker correspondence, 1965-1968
Articles and clippings
Miscellaneous notes and papers
Blank census forms and genealogical records forms
Oversize materials.

scopecontent.p: Boxes contain oversized materials of the collection. Oversize materials are correlated to boxes and folders in Family Files and Client Files.
